Posts.Content: 1flowergirl1 wrote: My mom was diagnosed with stage 1V bc in January. I can't even begin to imagine how many hours upon hours I have spent reading these forums. They have provided much comfort to me . When I thought there was no hope, I found it here. My mom is in her 70's and isn't comfortable on the computer. However, she is always glad to hear what new information what I have learned. Well, it has been one terrible roller coaster ride since January. I did not think it could get worse until my most recent mammogram. It showed a cluster of micro calcifications. I then had a diagnostic mammogram and now need a breast MRI. I just don't have time to be sick right now. I have to take care of my mom. I could never let her know if I also have breast cancer, that would be way too much for her to handle.  My sister is there on a daily basis and I go home for 6 days a month. When I go home I do all the difficult or heavy house hold chores (cleaning gutters, shopping, shoveling snow, weeding, etc). I have to be healthy to do all those things and don't have time for any treatments. All my FMLA is used to take care of my mom. I don't have a single sick or vacation day left to go for tests or treatments. I have not been able to find a way to tell my sister either. She really is at the end of her rope with worrying about and caring for my mom and raising twins with autism. I just can't put this on her. So, the two people who you would naturally turn to when worried about a possible breast cancer diagnosis, mom and sister, I need to protect. I'm a tad stressed out right now and just needed to vent. I can't imagine how much more stressed I would feel without this forum. Thank you from the bottom of my heart. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Mom's stage 1V and now my micro calcifications 1flowergirl1 SarahsMom
